questions.answer: Try to quiet it

questions.question: Explain why Emily Dickinson compares hope to a bird. (Insight 151)
questions.answer: Hope is compared to a bird because it is light, free and constantly uplifted, bringing comfort to the soul.

questions.question: Describe how hope behaves in difficult times according to the poem. (Insight 152)
questions.answer: Hope grows stronger when problems increase, like a bird singing louder in a storm, giving courage.

questions.question: How does the poem show that hope is generous? (Insight 153)
questions.answer: Hope asks for nothing but still supports people in sad or dangerous times. It gives warmth without expecting reward.

questions.question: Why is hope considered a source of inner strength? (Insight 154)
questions.answer: Hope keeps people going, providing mental strength during darkness, fear and struggle.

questions.question: Explain how personification is used in the poem. (Insight 155)
questions.answer: The poet treats hope as a living bird that sings, perches and provides warmth, showing personification clearly.
